OOC: Android: An automation in the form of a human being.

Cybernetics: The=
 study of human control functions and of mechanical and electrical systems =
designed to replace them. (cyborg isn't in the dictionary I got)

I think t=
hat explains things pretty well. I'd say that a cyborg is probably more ali=
ve than an android. Go, go, dictionary!...

  ----- Original Message -----
=
  From: In The Sky
  To: nbwrpg@yahoogroups.com
  Sent: Wednesday, August 2=
1, 2002 6:29 PM
  Subject: Re: Owlhawk's training


  OOC:  Yes, exactly.  =
A cyborg would be a human who has  been given robotic parts/stuff.  An andr=
oid would be a robot with an organic appearance.
    ----- Original Message=
 ----- 
    From: Hollywood Narrator 
    To: nbwrpg@yahoogroups.com 
    S=
ent: Wednesday, August 21, 2002 6:33 PM
    Subject: Re: Owlhawk's training=



    OOC: I do not believe he said that line in the original versions, ho=
wever, and I believe FUNimation inserted that. But even so, that would stil=
l classify them as cyborgs...

      ----- Original Message -----
      Fro=
m: Kyle Stewart
      To: nbwrpg@yahoogroups.com
      Sent: Wednesday, Aug=
ust 21, 2002 12:32 PM
      Subject: Re: Owlhawk's training


      OOC:  K=
rillan said 18 was originally a human, and Dr.
      Gero just modified her=
.  So I guess he didn't get
      around to taking away pain.

      --- Ho=
llywood Narrator <thecode@...> wrote:
      > OOC: Ah, I see. But i=
f you're using Dragon Ball Z as
      > an example, ( I said IF, I am not a=
ccusing) in Japan
      > they called them "Artificial Human" instead of
  =
    > androids. Keeping in mind that the English versions
      > are extre=
mely stupid, I wouldn't trust those suckas.
      > I myself would classify=
 the characters like 17 and
      > 18 of DBZ as cyborgs. King of like in T=
he
      > Terminator, except they feel pain where the
      > terminator d=
idn't. Geez, man, why did Dr. Gero make
      > his machines feel pain? I g=
uess so they can have the
      > ability to heal themselves like the Termi=
nator did
      > not.
      > 
      > Just me rambling on...
      >
